title: publish new crates

title: update dependencies
body:
- updates the version of a few github actions
- updates the nix flake
- fixes all linting errors called out by Clippy

title: Test release pipeline with new token
bump version to 0.14.0-pre.14
body: picking up `TrafficPolicy` changes so they can be propagated to the other SDKs

title: add support for TrafficPolicy
body:
### Why
The `ngrok` backend is now accepting a new field for policy called `TrafficPolicy`. Unlike the original `Policy` field which was a highly structured protobuf, this new field is simply a string. The SDK therefore needs to be supported to send this new String policy field to the backend.
Additionally, we want users who are using the old `Policy` field to still be able to use that until we fully deprecate inbound/outbound so they only have to update their code once. Therefore, this change also serializes the old `Policy` field as a JSON string and sends it to the backend as `TrafficPolicy`.

### How
The policy field in the proto representation was renamed to `TrafficPolicy` and changed to a new enum type called `PolicyWrapper`. This new enum allows it to be either a `String` (new configuration) or a `Policy` (old configuration). For string, this just gets sent as is, over the wire, which works. For `Policy`, a new serialization method was added to convert it into a string upon serialization. Additionally, the serialization for action configs had to be updated to convert it from a `Vec<u8>` to a `String`. 

In the BindOpts for each connection type, the `PolicyWrapper` is populated by either the `String` or the `Policy` type, depending on what the user set.

### Validation
Tunnels using the old `Policy` stuff and the new `TrafficPolicy` field were opened through the `axum` example. Both successfully started and had working policy.

A unit test was added to make sure `Policy` serializes and deserializes as we expect.

### Why did I update the flake?
I was getting an error from a number of different CI test, stating that the `#[diagnostic]` namespace is experimental. I found [this thread](https://github.com/tokio-rs/axum/discussions/2682) stating that it could be caused by using an outdated version of rust nightly. Considering we hadn't updated since Feb, I ran a quick `nix flake update` and everything seemed to work.

title: add rust language server to flake
body: ### Why For nix-based workflow, we often install language servers within the project we are working on. By including the language server here, someone using nix would have all the tooling they need just using the included flake. Additionally, it helps keep the LSP version in sync with the version of rust in the flake. ### Validation I'm using the Helix text editor to detect the presence of the rust-analyzer LSP. It does this by simply checking that `rust-analyzer` is in the current path. I also validated that the LSP works by opening one of the example files. #### Using old flake #### Using new flake

title: add bindings to ngrok-rust
body: add bindings mix-in to ngrok-rust

title: add root_cas
body:
Allow this on SessionBuilder:

- `.root_cas("trusted")`
- `.root_cas("host")`
- `.root_cas("/path/to/cert")`

Similar to: https://ngrok.com/docs/ngrok-agent/config/#root_cas

title: update nix for cargo-semver-checks 0.29
body: Fixes nix env on darwin: https://github.com/obi1kenobi/cargo-semver-checks/pull/647

title: Upgrade several dependencies
body: The big one here is `async-rustls`, which was deprecated wholesale in favor of `futures-rustls`. Most of the rest are pretty rote.

title: Add serde(default) back to policy parent struct
Add policies configuration
body:
The policies module allows users to attribute a set of rules that will be conditionally applied to the traffic associated with an edge. A single policy may have 0 to many cel expressions that evaluate to a boolean, and 1 to many actions that will execute if the aforementioned boolean is true.

Policies are classified as either inbound (apply to connections before they reach a backend) or outbound (apply to connections after they've come back from a backend).

title: ngrok: include url in error response Display implementation
ngrok: set the alpn field when app_protocol is specified
body:
If the upstream is a normal HTTPs server, it expects to have http/2 negotiated
via alpn. If alpn isn't provided, it will assume http/1.1. If our edge proxy is
sending down http/2 because `app_protocol` was specified, this results in a
protocol mismatch, and invalid requests/responses will be seen.

This ensures that the negotiation happens as expected.

title: feat: add app protocol
body:
## Why

We'd like to be able specify http2 when building an http tunnel

## How

Add `app_protocol` to the builder and plumb the `forwards_proto` into the session rpc.

## Validation

Run an example with the http2 app protocol and confirm the correct `forwardsProto` was set to `"http2"` or `""` .

title: add stale-issue project workflow
body: Add some automation, based on: https://docs.github.com/en/actions/managing-issues-and-pull-requests/closing-inactive-issues

title: ngrok: auto-rewrite the http host header
body:
This is now implemented by our request header middleware upstream, but this
adds some convenience and docs to it.

Users can call `http_builder.host_header_rewrite(true);` to have it set
automatically on `listen_and_forward` calls, and it also points out the
`.request_header(...)` approach to setting specific values.

Also canonicalizes (lowercases, really) header keys to make sure we aren't
sending multiple values for the same differently-cased "Host" header.

title: docs: cross-link the `forwards_to` builder methods to `listen_and_forward`
Add and update doc links
body:
More or less the same change as ngrok/ngrok-go#133.

Add the final destination links. ~I'll run a permalinking script after we've~
~agreed on the permalinks themselves.~ Per the updates in ngrok/ngrok-go#133, Product will handle the redirects, and these links are final.

title: ngrok: add Error impls for common pointer types
body:
Adds `Error` impls for `&` references, `Box`es, and `Arc`s where the type they
point to implements `Error`.

title: Make sure Ready is returned on proxy_proto remainder polling
body: If an inbound request is too small, no `poll_write` is issued to the outbound proxy stream by `copy_bidirectional`, so the data is never written to the inner stream. This adds returns `Ready` from remainder copying without condition, which resolves issue in an `ngrok-python` proxy test.

title: Use rustls for hyper-proxy
body:
Move `hyper-proxy` to use `rustls` which is already a dependency of the sdk, instead of the default of `native-tls`.
https://github.com/tafia/hyper-proxy#features

title: Forward proxy-protocol correctly to tls backends
body:
Currently, we ignore proxy protocol settings in our tunnels. This means that,
for tls and https connections that are terminated at the ngrok edge, the
incoming connections look like `ProxyProtoStream(PlainTextStream)`. When we
then terminate tls to the backend/upstream/whatever you want to call it, the
final stream looks like `TlsStream(ProxyProtoStream(PlainTextStream))`, where
it's expected to look like `ProxyProtoStream(TlsStream(PlainTextStream))`,
since proxy-protocol is a lower layer than TLS.

To that end, this change plumbs the proxy-proto setting through to the endpoint
connection object, reads the header out of the stream, and then makes sure to
write that to the upstream _first_ before terminating TLS.

title: update user agent filter comments
body:
originally this was for 
 `allow_user_agent` and `deny_user_agent` -> `allow_ua` and `deny_ua`  
to be consistent with `allow_cidr`/`deny_cidr

We decided not to change that naming since customer seems to like the longer name, but the comment still needs updating

title: add UserAgentFilter module
body: Resolves [#22193](https://github.com/ngrok-private/ngrok/issues/22193) This PR adds the UserAgentFilter module to ngrok-rust. To test the module locally: ```bash mkdir hello-ngrok cd hello-ngrok cargo init cargo add ngrok -F axum cargo add axum cargo add tokio -F rt-multi-thread -F macros ``` ```rs use axum::{routing::get, Router}; use ngrok::prelude::*; use std::error::Error; #[tokio::main] async fn main() -> Result<(), Box> { // build our application with a route let app = Router::new().route("/", get(|| async { "Hello from ngrok-rust!" })); // listen on localhost:8000 // axum::Server::bind(&"0.0.0.0:8000".parse().unwrap()) // .serve(app.into_make_service()) // .await?; // Ok(()) // listen on ngrok ingress (i.e. https://myapp.ngrok.dev) let listener = ngrok::Session::builder() .authtoken_from_env() .connect() .await? .http_endpoint() .allow_user_agent(r"foo/(\d)+") .allow_user_agent(r"bar/(\d)+") .deny_user_agent(r"buz/(\d)+") .listen() .await?; println!("Ingress URL: {:?}", listener.url()); axum::Server::builder(listener) .serve(app.into_make_service()) .await?; Ok(()) } ``` Run the following: ```bash NGROK_AUTHTOKEN="TOKEN" cargo r ``` Should get something like: ``` Ingress URL: "https://999c84cf6f3c.ngrok.app" ``` Ping the endpoint with `curl` to test results: ```bash curl --location you-domain.ngrok.app --header "User-Agent: " ``` Results: - Default Deny - Defined Deny - Assigned Allow Empty Unknown

title: misc: add code of conduct
body: Copied from our documentation repo.

title: Switch to forwarding based on URL and add TLS forwarding
body:
Switches us from the explicit tcp, http, and pipe forwarding methods to
accepting a URL. This should make it easier for us to update what
protocols we support without having to change the public API.

Eventually, we'll also be able to forward smarter with regards to tls,
proxyproto, etc. like the agent, but that'll come later.

title: ngrok: switch to mutable builder pattern
body:
Resolves #95

This also opens the way to allow builder methods to return `Results`, as
the builder won't be consumed in the event of bad input. Then, we can
push some validation to build time rather than connect time.

Combining this with a few other breaking changes, namely:
* No more `Error` stutter
* Validate the server addr at config time
* Validate the heartbeat config at config time
* Remove the server addr/heartbeat errors from the connect error enum
* Split the server addr into host/port when passing them to the connector

title: ngrok: support connecting through either http or socks5 proxies
body:
Resolves ngrok-private/ngrok#21250

Adds a `SessionBuilder::proxy_url` method that sets the session up to
connect via either an http or a socks5 proxy. As with `ngrok-go`, these
are mutually-exclusive with the `connector` and will override that
setting.

~~Errors from unsupported proxy schemes, like in `ngrok-go`, are deferred
to connect time. This isn't great, but we're kinda stuck with it since
builder method errors will consume the builder without hope of graceful
recovery, which is *also* bad. Might be time to re-evaluate #95.~~

Rebased this on #107, so we get config-time errors for unsupported proxies :tada:

title: ngrok: don't trim the ERR_NGROK prefix from error codes
body:
I got this wrong - we should be including the prefix to the error codes
after all. See
[this thread](https://github.com/ngrok/ngrok-go/pull/112#discussion_r1297876439) for context.

title: ngrok: parse error responses and surface the msg and code
body:
Resolves ngrok-private/ngrok#21498

Adds an `ErrResp` proto struct and an `NgrokError` trait.

The `ErrResp` gets parsed from the stringly-typed error message that
comes from tunnel protocol RPC calls, and holds both the messge and code
fields. The `NgrokError` trait allows us to bubble these fields up
through the `thiserror` wrappings to make it easier to get the ngrok
code/message at the top-level, i.e. `ConnectError` and `RpcError`.

title: Update README to include blog link; README header standardization
body: Part of https://github.com/ngrok-private/ngrok/issues/21276

title: Add feature Win32_Foundation, update nix for rust 1.72
body:
- Explicitly adding the `Win32_Foundation` feature of `windows-sys` to resolve https://github.com/ngrok/ngrok-rust/issues/99
- Adds a Windows build+test CI stage, removes long-tests from test-nix (but not test-stable) to be less-likely to trip packet blocking
- Updates nix `flake.lock`to move from rust `1.68` to `1.72` to get a clippy of at least `1.70` to pick up the now-required [let_with_type_underscore](https://rust-lang.github.io/rust-clippy/master/index.html#/let_with_type_underscore) lint
- Adds `resolver = "2"` to root `Cargo.toml` to remove resulting warn from the rust upgrade
- Removes a `mut` in [stream_manager.rs](https://github.com/ngrok/ngrok-rust/pull/101/files#diff-509c841b05c2bffa9f0cd523753190abc90adb8fef8d858bd881fc3951aff503) to appease the new clippy

Add comment to client_info
body:
Modeling off of [ngrok-go](https://github.com/ngrok/ngrok-go/blob/73d54eba1716e8889b7034f8ecd8071d69f8691a/session.go#L192).
Semver check fails, but this is a currently undocumented method, hopefully ok?

May want it to be `Option<Vec<String>>` to remove the `impl Into` so don't have to qualify a `None` like `None::<Vec<String>>`. Loses the flexibility, but makes the common case simpler.

title: reverse the UserAgent and skip the comma-separated shenanigans
body: See ngrok/ngrok-go#90.

title: make circuit_breaker test more resilient
body: Ran this [20 times in a row](https://github.com/ngrok/ngrok-rs/actions/runs/4661982577) and didn't see the circuit-breaker test fail. I was seeing about 1 in 3 fail the past two days otherwise (usually with an EOF error). This PR stops issuing new request batches once it sees a 503 response indicating that circuit breaking has kicked in, avoiding a flood of too many requests.

title: Move to latest watchexec, unpin bstr
body: Watchexec updated their dependencies, so now we can too: https://github.com/watchexec/watchexec/issues/503#issuecomment-1474870773

title: Add ca_cert option to SessionBuilder
body: Adds a `ca_cert` convenience method to SessionBuilder. This necessitated moving the creation of the default tls_config from `default` to `connect`.

title: switch tunnel_ext to tokio::io::copy_bidirectional
body:
Ran into an issue working with Django autoreloader. Django would close down its half of the connection on reload, but the next http request coming in over the tunnel would block. Traced it to the tunnel_ext which is doing a `join` on both sides. One side breaks out of its byte-shoveling loop but the other one keeps going, its write succeeded and there's nothing to read, so it never breaks and sends a FIN. Switching it to a [copy_bidirectional](https://docs.rs/tokio/latest/tokio/io/fn.copy_bidirectional.html) like this takes care of the issue.

_Previous description:_

Switching it to a `select` like this takes care of the issue, one future completes and drop's/muxado tears down the other side.

Is there a downside to moving to something like this? Thought about waiting on the other side for a short time to let it try and make more progress in case of a unidirectional issue. Probably unlikely?

Also don't know if this is how you'd want it implemented, `tokio` looks to have its own `select`, but this change uses `futures` like the `join` did.

title: ngrok: send the UserAgent when authenticating
body:
This brings it in-line with ngrok-go

Resolves #81

title: update ngrok-rs README
body: update readme with intro to ngrok-rs.

title: ngrok: update readme to clarify example
keep tunnel reference in forwarder to prevent drop
all: slightly decouple from the current execution context
body:
There are some spots (notably TunnelInner::drop) where we expect to be
in a tokio runtime context, and blindly call `tokio::spawn`, which
panics outside of the runtime.

Now, we grab a handle to the runtime at session (or heartbeat) startup,
and squirrel it away to use for future spawning, just in case it
happens outside of tokio.

This is probably the first step in decoupling from tokio entirely and
making both ngrok and muxado truly generic over the IO backend and
executor. That'll be a Big Change though, and might not happen until we
really need it.

body: Resolves https://github.com/ngrok-private/ngrok/issues/21879

title: ngrok: add support for "child" client types/versions
body:
Kinda rough/subject to change in the future, but at least it'll give us
a way to "stack" abstraction types and versions, like js, the agent,
etc.

The protocol semantics are almost certain to get an overhaul once we
figure out the "minimum version enforcement" feature, but for now, this
seems "good enough."

* Dropped the `_string` suffix from the cidr methods, since there are no alternatives

Basically the same change as muxado cancellation.

Tunnels already having a reference to the session ended up being really
convenient.

Resolves #57

title: muxado: include a go_away method on the opener
body: May or may not be useful for *aggressively* shutting down a session via the opener.

title: ngrok/muxado: add a user-definable heartbeat handler
body:
~~Not entirely happy with the mutex here. Might drop it back to non-mut/`Fn` rather than `&mut`/`FnMut`. It's fine for the single-restarting-session case, but cloning the builder and starting multiple concurrent sessions with it could cause problems since they'd be fighting to lock the handler.~~ No more mutex!

Consumers will have to deal with interior mutability themselves, but that seems fine-ish. It at least matches the command handlers.

title: muxado: cancel tasks when all references are dropped
body: Created a fancy-pants waitgroup implementation just for this purpose. I expect to make a similar change to the ngrok crate to shut down its background tasks as well once all tunnels and the session is dropped.

title: cargo-doc-ngrok: bump ngrok version
body: Not sure how this made it through CI the first time.

title: ngrok: add support for dashboard command handlers
body:
Not 100% happy with the `Fn` rather than `FnMut` constraint, but we can
probably loosen that later if it becomes too much of an issue.

I'm not sure if the fields to the update command actually get sent, or
if they're just some old meaningless cruft that we don't actually use
anymore.

Still need to do the local connection state callbacks, but I think those
are separate enough to warrant a different PR.

As an aside, I also noticed that the session/tunnels don't stop if there are
no reachable handles to them in consumer code. Like in the `mingrok`
example, both the session and tunnel stick around after a restart, and
even if you close the tunnel, the session is *still* hanging out. Going
to file a bug for that - probably something missed in the restart logic,
if not deeper.

title: ci: cache nix dependencies
body: Bumping my direnv action to 0.7, which now includes nix installation and direnv cache/import/export. Might hopefully speed things along a little bit, since we'll be fetching a single big archive from github rather than lots of little ones from the nixos cache.

title: ci: add sccache
body:
More CI caching!

No sccache for the tests with the github-provided stable toolchain, but that should be offset by the lack of direnv setup time.

title: handle non-camel-case in tls and tcp deserialization
body: Also adds a tls online test, `Scheme::from_str`, and a `forwards_to` example.

title: add tokio "net" feature to support tunnel_ext for cargo users
body:
`net: Enables tokio::net types such as TcpStream, UnixStream and UdpSocket, as well as (on Unix-like systems) AsyncFd and (on FreeBSD) PollAio.` https://docs.rs/tokio/latest/tokio/

Also add `libiconv` for darwin in nix, so don't have to use homebrew's.

This sed replaces the curl in the install.sh before handing to bash.

Uses github workflow token to get more rate limit: `secrets.GITHUB_TOKEN`
https://docs.github.com/en/actions/security-guides/automatic-token-authentication#example-2-calling-the-rest-api

title: bump muxado version for crates.io release
Update readme for application type
body: Noticed a copy pasta

title: Prepare for release on crates-io
body:
Still working on the upgrading guide.

We're going to start at v0.7.0 since the current `ngrok` crate on crates.io is at v0.6.0, and we don't want to break users. A minor version bump reflects a breaking change pre-1.0, so they won't accidentally switch from the wrapper to our new crate.

title: rust/tokio do not include unixstream at all on windows
body:
Adventures in Cross-Compiling found that UnixStream is not included at all in std on windows, so this PR cfg's it out.

Rust supports abstract linux sockets: https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/14194
But not windows 10 or 11's unix sockets: https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/56533
There is a crate to support uds on windows, will look into that at some point (along with windows pipes): https://crates.io/crates/uds_windows

title: ci: Add release checks and jobs
body:
Alright, I'm reasonably happy with this now. Semver checks now happen before PR merge, and once it hits master, it'll always try to publish, and if the publish succeeds, it'll add a git tag for us.

So all we have to do to publish is make a PR with a version bump!

title: tunnel: plumb the original metadata back out through the tunnel object
body: Looks like we missed this the first time around, and it came up while writing tests.

title: features: make the hyper and axum support optional
body: Also a bit of feature groundwork for the online tests.

title: tunnel proto fixes
body:
I'm rolling up any protocol changes needed to get #38 working here to keep things somewhat organized.

For the most part, this is just making sure that these structs I added match the json representation generated by protoc, which annoyingly is *completely different* from the hand-written Go structs. This means that all of their fields get defaulted and omitted if they're default, as well as snake_cased, *except* for the `Headers::add_parsed` field, which is inexplicably camelCase in the proto definition.

title: online testing
body: These tests will verify this crate against the live ngrok servers, and should mirror the online tests in `ngrok-go`.

title: add cargo-doc-ngrok
body: Pretty bare-bones for now - builds the docs and serves them up via an ngrok tunnel using ngrok-rs and hyper.
